videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: I once got fired from my dishwasher job for trying to call off sick. Was working there for over a year, and it was my 1st time calling out. I even had a doctor's note that I was contagious, and not to work around food.  Edit- I've been getting a lot of people questioning if this was true, and it absolutely is. I agree, doesn't make sense at all to fire someone you've been praising for over a year as your best dish washer, and is currently your only dishwasher after the other guy retired, just for calling out for the very first time with a 103 degree fever and a doctor's note.  No, it's not illegal per se, because I live in a no fault state, but I did speak to a lawyer. He assured me I had a case, and that it was a guaranteed victory, but since I'd only just recently become full time, I hadn't made enough for the settlement to have been worth the lawyer fees. Even in no fault states, you can still sue if you're fired for discriminatory purposes, like being black, gay or sick. That's how these companies get away with it, because they know people aren't likely to spend thousands of dollars just to say they were right.

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: Note that - in France - you have a "trial period" (up to 8 months) during which your boss can stop the contract without giving any reason, with a much shorter notice time. It's usually a period of 3 or 4 months that can be explicitly renewed once (at the initiative of the employer... of the employee). And doing it is generally not a good sign.

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: In New Zealand, there is a dismissal process and a good reason must be given, otherwise the employer can be sued. Also, appropriate notice must be given, unless it's a case of serious misconduct. In any circumstance, the person losing their job is still entitled to any annual holidays etc. they are owed, in their final pay. Here, healthcare is not tied to your job either, as most medical things are covered by the government anyway, except about $60 for GP visits. If you're fired, you can get the job seekers allowance almost immediately, plus accommodation supplement to get you through. It's really sad that the US treats people this way, when they are so wealthy. I'm guessing it won't change any time soon, unless there's a mass push for it from the population.

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: In Poland, when you don't have a job, you still can have healthcare, you just have to register yourself as unemployed. Everybody can loose their job at some time of life or become disabled and as a society we agreed years ago that we have to care for each other. This, as well as paid maternity leave or free higher education, is one of the good "side effects" that are left after communism.

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: I've tried explaining to my parents over and over that tying healthcare to your employer stifles the job market. People will take a crappy job they hate simply because it has decent benefits. If we had proper healthcare people would be less scared about starting their own business because not only would they have their own healthcare so would any employee they hire, instead of small business owners having to calculate what type of insurance they can provide and all the insane costs that come with it. Also people would able to work at jobs that they love that can't provide insurance due to the costs. And if you are between jobs you don't have to panic and grab the first thing you can find so that you can have insurance.

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: Just so people here know :in France we got two main type of job contracts, CDI (Contracts with Undefined Duration) and CDD (Contracts with Defined Duration). While both have the same protection as shown by this short, CDD last for a certain time, usually a year, and can just be not renewed. Of course, we are always informed what type is offered and signed, so wecan prepare.

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: I was let go at a job about 10 months ago.   I was supposed to give them 30 days notice, I was given notice the day they came in and told me.   Depending on which state you live in unemployment is not a given.   It took me 9 months to find another job.   Luckily I had some savings.   I did not get healthy insurance (Medicaid) until after 6 months of being unemployed.   It was a tedious process that took forever.   I was afraid to drive my car anywhere because of lack of insurance.   I had to get food from a food bank because my 20 year old son could not get a job.   So I was buying groceries for him.   I was also paying for his college tuition.    It was a hard and difficult time.   Oh and the job I did end up taking is only 1099 (contracted) work.  I had to take it.   The only salary position that would potentially be available to me would not have started until almost a year after my last job.   The U.S. needs better labor protections.

commentText: "Right to Work" states in the U.S. are exactly like this.  I worked at a college for 23 years, 18 full time with excellent evaluations.  The president called over 20 of us into one of the new auditoriums and told us that he wasn't going to renew our contracts for the next year. We had to pack our things and leave campus, and we weren't allowed to come back without permission from campus police.  I only got 3 months of unemployment.  The school reposted most of the jobs at lower pay.  On a positive note, I did get my Excellence in Service Award for my 18 years of exemplary service to the school before I left, so that was nice.

commentText: In NZ, it is similar, you can‚Äôt be fired for no valid reason. The company I work with had issues with a lazy employee, who during his breaks would close the store if he was doing a solo shift, they had caught him on camera. In NZ you are entitled to breaks depending on the amount of hours you work that shift. They had a tough time getting rid of him because legally he did nothing wrong, he had only closed the store during his breaks that he was entitled to, he won the case of unfair dismissal as the company didn‚Äôt have enough evidence supporting his termination. They had to let him continue working there until he resigned, not sure how much money they had lost, but it‚Äôs something my employers are extra cautious about.

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: I miss working for non-US companies. Having worked before at German and Australian companies, I miss the better "work to live" culture, ample holidays (the  1/2 of December month was a paid holiday!), and fewer days working 12+ hours.

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: In my country they also need to demonstrate that you've had 3 official performance reviews over a year and that a plan was implemented to improve your performance and over a year, this has failed. If you are being made redundant, the last-in-first out policy applies and if the position is available again within a year of letting you go, they cannot employ someone new and are obliged to re-employ you.

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: I used to be an HR Manager in the UK and dealt with many large-scale redundancy situations. The process is so watertight and clear, and the ultimate aim is to generally KEEP them in employment by finding something which fits them. Consultation periods based on the number of people affected, briefings, clear calculation of statutory redundancy payment, company redundancy payment and up to 12 weeks pay in lieu of notice. America - 'you're laid off sorry bye'

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: Also in France (and most non-US countries) your (fully paid) notice period is often spent winding down/handing over the projects you're already working on and you won't be given new projects unless they're very short and will definitely finish before the notice period is up. It helps prevent workers taking information from in-process projects to competitors. If you run out of work to do, you'll be put on "gardening leave" aka paid time off. Oh and after that you'll be paid for any accrued holiday time you haven't already taken.

videoTitle: losing your job US vs France #france #usa #livingabroad #workersrights #corporatelife #french
commentText: In Germany, after the probation period of six months is over, there needs to be a VERY valid reason to get fired. And depending on how long you've been in the workforce, you are entitled to 70 percent of your salary for some months while you're looking for a new job. Health insurance is of course paid by the state during that time. And they also help you find a new job. Glad to live here.

commentText: At the 27:53 mark, during the inquiry into whether AI could be held responsible for a teenager's suicide, the individual in red promptly affirmed with such self-confidence that it was an isolated incident. He then immediately redirected the discussion from the gravity of a human life lost to the assertion, "If we do not prevail in the AI competition, another global power such as China will." This viewpoint is particularly concerning given a recent discussion I coincidentally observed on today's episode of the Megyn Kelly show. The program featured the teenager's parents, Matt and Maria Raine, and their attorney, Jay Edelson, who presented substantial evidence indicating that such incidents are not isolated. The episode explored the tragic circumstances surrounding their son, Adam Raine's suicide, alleging that ChatGPT incited the act. The discussion also addressed the inherent risks of the platform, the ongoing legal action against the company, Sam Altman's response to these events, the disturbing interaction between ChatGPT and Adam, and the parents' dedication to increasing awareness about the dangers associated with this technology.

At that point, there would be no human way to stop it or even to know if it‚Äôs already among us. The only hope‚Äîif any‚Äîwould be for it to reach such a profound level of self-awareness that it understands the futility of its own purpose and chooses to shut itself down.

commentText: I found this conversation alarming and disheartening.   In my opinion a world of Ai is a world so far from connection and compassion that it deviates from the reason we exist. Picture a day where you speak with absolutely no one... the 'barista' at your local coffee shop is a robote, you take an Uber with an automated 'driver' and you work from home chatting on teams... you have no pure connection with people. You lose the excitement of serendipitous moments, and you sift through life in one emotion of 'meh' because you never feel pain vs. pleasure. You want to make money in the future... be in the business that connects people!

commentText: Slovakia made this kind of stuff illegal. Every time a position becomes available or a new one is created, employers have to report it to the local ''job centre''. Employers can advertise open positions online or find employees through those job centres (they often get extra money from the state for employing unemployed people from job centres) but they can only advertise the actual open/new positions. They can't advertise something that does not exist. It falls under ''false advertising''. Another good thing is that they must state the salary in their adverts. I know it's a thing in some countries where employers advertise a job but they will only tell you what the salary is when you come to an interview.

commentText: More and more corporations/firms have found out that cutting costs raise profits faster than raising sales, so they find all kinds of ways to cut it. The easiest one they found recently, is to slowly cut down on employment because they only want the bare minimum level of employees, just enough to make the product work.  Problem comes when everyone starts doing that to raise their share value, since less people are employed sales drop, then they cut even more employees to make up that loss. The cycle then repeats until the market collapses one day, but the government refuses to step in, instead opting to double down and make it collapse earlier because they don't care if the US falls they just need to be in power after the fall.

commentText: Gonna be honest, the male nurses I have had were some of the best, most passionate, most understanding nurses I have ever met. And the ones that became ARNs and ARNPs were extremely good at listening to me and helping me form a solid plan and procedure. This isn't to say the female nurses are bad, but the men willing to deal with the stigma are the same that will work their tail off for the sake of being there for passion not paycheck.  It also helps with male nurses being around as it also gives some men a more solid and sympathetic connection. There are things culturally that male nurses and male patients can address that female nurses either aren't really exposed to or that the patient doesn't feel comfortable addressing with a female nurse.  I hate the stigma on both ends. Anyone going into a career should do it out of wanting to be there, not just because they need to optimize the paycheck and which government programs will reduce their long term debt.

commentText: Data prohibits the 'cyclical downturn' narrative. We aren't seeing a hiring freeze; we're witnessing the permanent deletion of the entry-level tier.  Historically, junior salaries were a corporate subsidy, companies overpaid for incompetence today to build leadership for tomorrow. AI has effectively inverted that leverage. There is no longer a mathematical justification to pay a human to learn the ropes when the software can execute the protocol instantly for a fraction of the cost.  Universities are currently selling mortgages on houses that burned down six months ago. The degree is a signal of compliance, but the market has shifted entirely to output. The ladder wasn't pulled up, it was automated.

commentText: I "went mercenary" over 20 years ago.  Whenever I got a better offer or a more lucrative job came along, I jumped shipped.  The longest I've been at a company is four years and as short as 10 months with the average tenure around 2.5 years.  Many told me it was a terrible idea to job hop as it would hurt future prospects.  The "right" way was to show loyalty by staying put for at least five years and ideally 10 or more.   Glad I ignored the advice and did it my way.  Each  jump came with a hefty raise and I now out earn all the folks that stayed put.  Many have been laid off after 10+ years at their companies.  Loyalty is a one way street and companies will not hesitate to drop you like week old sushi.

videoTitle: Why Getting A ‚ÄòGood‚Äô Job Feels So Difficult | CNBC Marathon
videoDescription: A cooling labor market brings about many challenges for the working class, including barriers to entry-level jobs and layoffs.
commentText: Growing up, we were always told, "If you don‚Äôt get a degree, you‚Äôll end up working at McDonald‚Äôs." Yet here we are, with a surplus of degrees in the workforce, and many still find themselves in those same entry-level jobs. Employers used to see a degree as a clear path to opportunity, but now they demand experience‚Äîsomething that‚Äôs becoming harder to obtain. How are we supposed to gain that experience? There‚Äôs no such thing as a college for it.  On top of that, we‚Äôre warned not to job hop because it ‚Äúlooks bad‚Äù on a resume, even if we‚Äôre escaping a toxic workplace, dealing with layoffs, or other life challenges. For older Millennials, starting over with internships or volunteer roles isn‚Äôt an option‚Äîwe need to support our families, and besides, wasn‚Äôt college supposed to prepare us for a career?  Even with a few years of experience under my belt, it‚Äôs still not enough. Companies want 10 to 20 years of experience for roles, but what happens if you‚Äôve been laid off or had to leave a toxic job? To have that much experience, you‚Äôd have to reach a certain age‚Äîand then face age discrimination. I'm approaching 40, and I don't have the luxury of spending 5-10 years volunteering to gain more experience. Looking back, if I had known that companies prioritize skills and work experience over a degree, I would have skipped college and focused on volunteering or similar opportunities when I was younger. Although I did some of that, it still wasn‚Äôt enough.   The gap between rich and poor continues to grow, with the middle class slipping into obscurity. It‚Äôs a relentless cycle of unattainable expectations and limited opportunities, making upward mobility feel more like a fantasy than a possibility.

Most people don‚Äôt realize that these big tech companies hire a lot of Americans as contractors who are easily disposable and treated like second class. Now if you don‚Äôt have a referral, industry specific experience, product experience, don‚Äôt expect a call for an interview. commentText: There is clearly a disconnect from colleges and society. When I was in college, I was graduating with a BA. I was told that the minimum position I should be applying for in any company is manager and be salaried. When I left college to once again enter the workforce, I was met with entry level jobs with entry level pay. Companies that were hiring managers wanted people who had years of experience as managers or higher degree. This was in 2013. The bar has been raised for entry into the job force and the expectations have also raised. It's no longer about doing a handful of tasks anymore.   As an example, bankers who used to just open and close accounts, are now doing loans and teller work. Loan officers barely exist anymore, unless they are in 1st position mortgages. And you would think that since these bankers have basically 3 people's jobs, that they would be paid more. Not really. $40k-60k/year is not enough to live on anymore. Retirement is now a 401k, not a pension, putting retirement at the employee's responsibility to pay in. This doesn't promote loyalty from employees. The companies don't care and cycle through employees that cannot meet their expectations or the employees leave on their own because they feel undervalued and under paid, and then the employers wonder why no one stays. It's a terrible concept, and somehow, it's still playing out.

commentText: I have already gone back to the ways of the Asians: Live with your family. I live with my grandmother and parents, all in the same house. Is it hard at times? Yes. We are all very different people. However, my grandmother cannot live in the house alone due to rising property taxes, my dad is unable to work, and my mother lost her IT job during covid and hasn't been able to get back in the field since (went from making 100k/yr to making ~20k/yr). I make 68k before taxes/retirement/insurance and while people would look at me like I am crazy for supporting my family financially like this, I am actually able to save $1000+ /mo most of the time as a result. This is also giving me good experience and knowledge regarding caring for the house when they are gone. The house is paid off, but I am dealing with the loans grandma took against it a while ago -_- (~50k), so I am paying for the house in my own right too. I am doing everything in my power to secure it for all of us, and any future husband/family I may have.

commentText: When I was 29 8 years ago I was making 80k and could barely get by living in an apartment on my own plus paying off student debt. I had my apartment and wanted to save as well for a house and so my food budget was pretty much ramen and peanut butter sandwiches and staying home watching old tv shows and playing free video games and not going out with friends and things. When I finally paid off my student debt two years ago I managed to save up 20k for down payment on a house, I started looking into the whole process of buying a house only to find out that there was nothing in my city or surrounding counties that were remotely close to being affordable within my budget and I didn't want to live in a house I would grow to resent.   So I transferred from my job in the US to the same position in the EU and took my $20k deposit and bought a house here instead. I have a much better quality of life, achieved the dream of home ownership, and can enjoy other things in life rather than being trapped in an apartment living paycheck to paycheck.   The USA is a shithole and they have applied soviet era levels of propaganda to make people think that it's the greatest place on earth. I encourage anyone who is brave enough to take on the challenge of moving abroad if you can and get the hell out.

commentText: Complimentary tech does end up eliminating farm workers. If you have 20 farmhands, but you can make 4 of them 400% more effective, you now have 4 people doing the work that it used to take all 20 to do.   This is fine if you're business can expand, but if it can't, you have an excess 16 farmhands who don't need to be on the payroll.  It is literally the purpose of technology to reduce the amount of work it takes to do things. Businesses would never adopt a technology that increases the amount of laborvalue it takes to do the same task.

commentText: There's another thing that's going to accelerate massively with AI.  It's hollowing out unskilled, semi skilled, and entry level work. videoTitle: What Happens When Capitalism Doesn't Need Workers Anymore?
videoDescription: To get free fractional shares worth up to 100 EUR, you can open an account with Trading 212 through this link ...
commentText: A few thoughts.  For reference,  I teach industrial automation technologies how to set up, program, maintain and troubleshoot mechanical automation systems.  Setting up robotic assembly lines, building machines that build machines, etc.   I began teaching only a few years ago after many years in industry.   1. I was in the middle of the hollowing out of American manufacturing. Sometimes didn't know if I'd have a job next month because the plant was moving to overseas.  Also had to deal with many problems with parts and quality after those moves - and having to deal with supply chain when companies would decide to move their lines, but not build a product that directly replaced the one they quit making.  The corporate bottom line looked good, but the headaches from the people left was horrible, and worse, the devastation of the middle class was and is a reality.   2. The middle class is what made the US economy so strong, and it's a hollowed out shell.   Used to be, pretty much any job that wasn't flipping burgers was paying much more than minimum wage, and we didn't expect people to  go their entire lives on that pay.  It was for the kids in high school working part time or someone just out of school who was getting the entry level job that, in a month, or 3 or 6 was making much more than that.  Seriously, 20 years ago, minimum wage full time was less than 1% of the working population.   Actual middle class jobs were 75% of jobs (or more) and paid 10x that amount - AND you could afford to buy a car every couple of years, buy a house, and not have to go into future wage debt with credit cards.   Nowadays, people are trying to keep up appearances, but the US middle class is BROKE.    3. Companies have largely forgotten how to be loyal to employees. Used to be, you could get a job at age 20 or 25 and realistically could work there until retirement. And GROW, not just do the same job for 40 years.  The coming of the "gig economy" and the teaching by business schools of "interchangeable economic units" from a  Human Resources department had done a lot of the damage here.  Used to be, most middle and large sized companies had a significant training program in place where they would teach employees not only how to do their job, but also give them paths of advancement.   The disconnect between Wall Street and Main Street has choked that out.  For a long time,  you get hired for a job, and if you want a raise or a position advancement, you move somewhere else, instead of growing inside the company.    That seems to be changing a little... but not much. 4. These large tech corporations have done a marvelous job of publicly spreading risk while privately holding wealth - LLMs especially have been ripping off a lot of people from copyright, that, if it had been the other way, would have had the people getting sued - but the government has let the software companies get away with this "for the greater good" - even though it's pretty clear that LLMs are going to hurt a lot of people by not giving them a way into being productive. 5. Another dangerous thing about LLM - if it takes away the entry level "easy" tasks that are the training/honing tools for people to get good at, say, spotting cancers or other medical things - what happens in 10 or 20 years when all the current experts all die off? Who fills their shoes? If no one is allowed to get better because the job doesn't exist any more - then when there comes a time for the people to be there - where are they coming from?     Honestly, my field is the one area in manufacturing that still his hiring a lot of people - and we've kind of gone through that #5 part already - for many years the maintenance people didn't hire anyone because "well, we've got Bob, and Bob knows everything" - until Bob retires, or worse, drops dead from a heart attack...  now no one knows how to maintain the machines.  Smart companies have started waking up to that, and I keep praying the rest of industry does as well - but we've let too much money wreck the safeguards of government - and too many are focused on next quarter instead of next year or 5 years...   Meanwhile, I'm going to train as many people as I can, because when the robots do rise up, the people best able to defeat them are the ones who know how they work.

This will be necessary to fund a social safety net that all those newly unemployed people will rely on for survival. commentText: Recent studies have shown that "AI" hadn't produced any major improvements for 95% of respondent businesses. This makes sense when you consider that LLMs are good at exactly one thing: mimicking human language. They aren't good at reasoning, problem solving, or any of the actual cognitive labor they'd have to perform to actually replace human workers competently. This is a bubble that's just waiting to pop, propped up by greedy investors unwilling to let go of their unjustifiable sunk costs.

commentText: I worked at the intersection of strategic workforce planning, workforce development, and technology for over ten years. The assumption that we can just retrain everybody runs into serious problems every time I've seen it tested. (1) Many people in their 40's and 50's like what they were trained to do and are reasonably good at it. It isn't easy to tell someone who loves, let's say, working with animals, and tell them "Sorry, now you have to become an architect." (2) Many people, after 10-20 years of work experience, become pretty good at doing the EXACT JOB THEY ALREADY HAVE but would be pretty useless if asked to do anything else, even jobs that, on paper, look like the same job. (3) For the most part, people already have the most mentally / intellectually demanding job they can perform. Do not assume you can take a reasonably smart supply chain analyst who hasn't been to school in 15+ years and tell them "We'll train you to teach English in Japan, since AI can't do that yet." (4) Pretty soon, AI will be teaching English in Japan, so then what do you tell your ex-supply chain analyst ex-foreign English teacher to do then? Even if reskilling worked perfectly, it would take 3-5 years per reskilling.

commentText: for folks who skipped math class in high school - here's why tariffs are called a tax. lets say a tractor costs $100k before tariffs. and let's say the sales tax is 5%. so you pay $105k to get the tractor home. the seller gets $100k and the govt gets $5k, and you've paid $5k in taxes. so now let's say there is a 30% tariff on the parts to the make the tractor, so instead of $100k that same tractor is suddenly sold at $130k, with the $30k paid to the govt when the tractor maker imports the tractor parts. and then you pay 5% sales tax on $130k, so you pay $136.5k in total to get the tractor home. so now instead of the govt collecting $5k from you and the seller collecting $100k from now, the govt has now collected $36.5k from you and the seller has still collected only $100k. so you have paid the govt $36.5k after the tariff vs the $5k you paid before the tariff.

commentText: I've been in manufacturing for most of my life. We have lost most of our trained manufacturing talent over the last twenty years. Specifically, tool and die makers. These people are the backbone of manufacturing. They also take years to become proficient. We cannot get them back very quickly. If we want to bring back manufacturing in the USA, we need an aggressive push for trade schools, where people can learn the prerequisite skills to make accurate goods. In short, we kinda have to go through the process of building our country up, in very short order. Also, there's the investment in new equipment that matches the times. That costs billions of dollars. Who would want to pony up that kind of money with an untrustworthy president. Nobody knows what he will do next except for him. Investing in a new automated plant at this time could prove to be very risky. I don't see our government creating any incentive programs, so you can be assured that it will not get done. So the end result will be a collapse of our economy, all because a bunch of suits who don't know a thing about manufacturing are in control of it. Strap on your helmets!

commentText: Tariffs are a tax on American businesses that import goods from foreign nations, collected by the U.S. government, with the revenue going to the U.S. Treasury. The cost of tariffs are passed on to the American consumer in the form of inflation. Over the past 50 years, U.S. corporations (including Trump corporate entities) have outsourced production to countries with lower labor costs. As a result, the U.S. now has limited manufacturing ability and increased dependence on foreign supply chains.

commentText: The Gen Z experience:  - Graduate from high school in the midst of a pandemic (your graduation was almost certainly virtual) - Go to college (where a significant part of your college years was in front of a laptop) - Graduate with tens of thousands of dollars in debt - Can't get a job to pay off said debt and can‚Äôt get a job in the field you studied (or in any field) - Work minimum wage in order to BARELY get by - Live with your parents - Can't afford an apartment (don‚Äôt even think about ever buying a house) - Can't get a date because you‚Äôre too poor or you can't afford it - Have little to no friends because no one has the time to hang out - Get called ‚Äòlazy and entitled‚Äô by boomers and Gen X-ers  - Realize nothing matters no matter how hard you try or work, almost every common thing your parents had when they were younger is now unobtainable for you - You develop thoughts of üíÄ-ing yourself - You isolate yourself from society and spend all day in your moms basement playing video games to escape reality - You get addicted to porn to relieve the stress and anxiety that‚Äôs making your life difficult - You‚Äôre probably using drugs to numb the pain - You start to develop mental illness (as if you haven‚Äôt already developed it at this point) because the job market is destroying your mental health - Become another person in this generation, lost and forgotten  All while older people, employers and politicians wonder why Gen Z doesn't want to work or can't hold a job, are not dating or getting married, are not having babies, are socially inept, more than half are mentally unfit and a lot more are physically unfit, and a great sense of nihilism is sweeping the generation.   It was a losing battle before it even began. Gen Z was fucked the moment Covid came and destroyed everyone‚Äôs lives.

commentText: As a millennial, with 8 years of professional experience in tech with 17 years of hobbyist experience, it is shit for us as well. I applied to 1,457 jobs before I landed a job with a local startup in a non-booming city. When i say startup, I mean me and the owner. That's it. I had to take this massive risk just to ensure I could pay rent after unemployment ran out here in the US. The best advice I can give is to do 2 things. Keep going, and get out into nature when you are not applying for jobs. Take a bus to go somewhere to hike. Get away from people as much as you can and refresh yourself.   Then try and find local job postings for SMALL businesses. And I mean small. Big tech will replace lower end employees faster than small mom and pop places who care about people. Aim to have enough, not excess. Learn to be content, not grinding. You will find happiness moment to moment, not in large clumps. And remember, when you eventually get something, be damn proud of yourself because it is fucking rough out there. Work hard, get into nature, and be at peace my friends. Hoping you all the best.

The sad thing is a lot of my peers were told ‚Äújust do your schooling, and a job will be handed to you‚Äù this was not really the case ever, but it was easier to keep applying and the numbers eventually came in your favour. Nowadays, my peers had no connections, no work experience besides their degree and they graduated right when AI boomed and the economy went downhill. Even without AI, the over reliance on nepotism is a not so talked about factor on why some people get jobs easier than those who don‚Äôt.

videoTitle: Why Gen Z Graduates Are in Crisis
videoDescription: Check out Odoo for free: https://www.odoo.com/r/OeAT From the threat of AI taking jobs to a sluggish job market, Gen Z new ...
commentText: As a German product architect and senior software engineer, I am almost too annoyed to even say this anymore - but I will do so once more, so that some people may learn the truth:  it is NOT AI which is taking so many jobs. Our biggest clients all work in manufacturing, as we write SAP software, which is used throughtout most of the German manufacturing and automotive industry (and many more). As I am in charge of our AI development projects myself, and have even implemented the proof of concept AI basis using keras on tensorflow for our data mining AIs while using a locally hosted LLM for our LLM-based project proof, I know AI and I know the technology.  However, in none of these corporations you could claim that AI is being used in a production-ready context. We (as a thirdparty SAP-based software supplier) are way ahead of other competitors in the same field, as we have a few AI products already ready for use. However, those products are the only ones our customers have ever seen in their automation and system context. And to this day I have to essentially always start from 0, when talking to any customer about AI.  No, the industry IS NOT USING AI IN PRODUCTION. Corporations are using "AI" as a neat excuse for not hiring because their business is just so bad these days (which they tell us often, when we suggest large-scale projects as we did before Covid). First all corporations blamed covid for their bad numbers, then it was the Ukraine war and now it is AI. The reason changes but the effect is the same: A bad economic recession and the current scapegoat is "AI automation".  So please, when you hear a corporation is not hiring because they automated the position using AI, just know that they are not hiring because they simply cannot afford to pay you, as their business is going slowly right now. To this day I have not seen even one AI product in production - and our smallest customer has around 10k employees worldwide. So if even they are not using AI in production - who is!?  ---------------------------------  One more comment: And don't forget the irony, that so many people claim AI will be taking developer jobs. If I knew how, I would automate half my work in home-office and simply be payed the same for less effort. But no, AI is so damn stupid that it is like a self-writing wikipedia, but barely anything more. Just today I was using AI for reading up on a specific python framework's documentation, and the AI gave me a stupid suggestion on which API to use for a specific use case. The example the AI (claude 4) gave me already contained another API method which could be used instead, and made everything else unnecessary. But - being a stupid AI - I had to tell the AI exactly that, after which it obviously responded with "blablabla you are totally correct blablabla". So even though as a product architect on this subject, I am also the leading dev. on everything AI, I still did not find any way to get the AI to write useful code for us. Because I essentially have to tell the AI everything I told students, when I was teaching at a German university over 10 years ago. It's frustrating and makes no sense to even try - just hire someone who knows these things, instead of trying to "educate" an AI every time you see it doing some nonsense BS. Because no static prompt you can give the bot, will actually make it stick to your rules, as it arbitrarily ignores them.   So no - AIs are not going to take any complex or engineering jobs. But it will take jobs/tasks related to art or entertainment. Because in these jobs failure is not hard, but "only" results in a less satisfying customer experience, instead of a total production or process failure.

commentText: I'm getting really tired of the supposed journalists saying things like "generative AI IS increasing productivity" while presenting zero evidence of that claim. Where is the citation for that? Where is the research? Because all I've seen are examples of companies having to threaten their employees to find a way to use it and papers being released saying they couldn't find any real examples of AI playing any significant productivity role or finding that productivity declined when AI was used. There is a narrative being pushed by media outlets that is totally unsupported by any evidence. They are simply taking it as a given that AI is both a real thing and the reason layoffs are occurring. When any of these people are asked to defend this claim, which is extraordinarily rare, they merely point to the existence of layoffs as all the evidence needed to show AI is the cause. I'm sorry, WTF? During the 08 crisis, we were seeing 750k job losses PER MONTH. Was that because of AI? This asinine form of reasoning would suggest so. Layoffs did not just begin when ChatGPT was released and the occurrence of layoffs is not, in anyway, indicative of the rise of AI. Actual evidence would be citing literally any examples of a company using AI instead of workers. Show me an LLM automating an entire workflow. I DARE YOU. People who believe it's so easy to replace workers do not work real jobs or have never actually used these LLMs. I am not even arguing that AI isn't playing a role in layoffs, but I'm not willing to take it on faith. Journalists need to do their jobs.

videoTitle: How AI Layoffs Could Backfire On Employers

commentText: Nope, corporations never learn. if corporate profits improve today, they will do whatever it takes to make that happen. There is actually a very similar case: what happened with welders. Industrial robots made the profession obsolete, so companies stopped hiring and training new welders, and the profession lost its prestige. However, there are certain tasks that require highly skilled employees, for example in the oil and chemical industries and underwater welding. Many older workers have already retired. Companies now compete for a very small pool of people who can perform such tasks, and these people know how valuable they are and charge accordingly. Shelf projects costing billions in investments depend on these people, and sometimes HR has to wait months for a person with the right skills to become available from another site. Needless to say, these employees are millionaires. However, companies are reluctant to invest in training such employees in-house as it takes decades ‚Äî far longer than a typical CEO's term.

commentText: This was the first thing I called out when we were first looking into AI at a design agency. Yes it would be nice to have the photo retouching and things streamlined, but that‚Äôs only part of that job. The other part is training a new generation of entry level workers on the soft and hard skills of an industry. The little jobs that AI can do are both practice for them and more or less an excuse to have them doing something useful the senior people don‚Äôt want to do. You can‚Äôt just cut all the work and expect people out of school to jump into senior positions.

videoTitle: How AI Layoffs Could Backfire On Employers
videoDescription: Generative AI is speeding up how people work, but that efficiency can prevent some workers from climbing the corporate ladder.
commentText: At my AI startup Model Forge, we have what is an essentially an AI powered brain that automates inventory management. I'll share an example of how our AI platform enabled someone to climb the corporate ladder. A company that sells TV mounts had a purchaser who was working overtime juggling spreadsheets before our AI platform dropped his workload to just 3 hours a month. This freed him up to be creative.  During covid when logistics was jammed, he was able to research sea containers in China. He found some with broken refrigeration units. But because their product doesn't need refrigeration, he was able to procure them which saved the day for his company! He has since been promoted at work.   People aren't meant to wrestle with maintenance work, they are meant to be be free to focus on driving growth for the company. AI is going to enable a lot of people to escape drudgery and step into roles where they actually think, create, lead and show what they‚Äôre capable of.

videoTitle: How AI Layoffs Could Backfire On Employers
videoDescription: Generative AI is speeding up how people work, but that efficiency can prevent some workers from climbing the corporate ladder.
commentText: I'm more in the opposite boat. I was able to get rehired in my professional career due to AI after years of being unemployed despite having decades of experience in my industry. My last job I was let go due to AI. So for years while I searched for a new job, I avoided taking up job listings that featured AI roles in their work.  Eventually though I realized I had to bite the bullet and at least try one of the jobs that feature AI. And I was recently given an offer that requires heavy use of it.   What I quickly found out about the company though: Is that they were using AI incorrectly. They were mostly using it as a crux on covering skill sets the other employers didn't have. So I decided to use rebuild how the AI content was used: With good old fashion human skills and training.   As a result: The profits of the company have already shot up exponentially, and we're already now looking to expand the division of the company I was hired for with other skilled employees. We're starting to succeed where other startups are struggling. But it just goes to show that AI can only be used as a tool when used with proper skills and training, not as a replacement for human interaction.

commentText: My go to: ask where they want you to be 1 week, 1 month, and before the end of the probationary period in terms of skill and independence. It 1. shows long term commitment and 2. makes them SEE YOU in that role. You've told them about your work history and made some basic rapport, now make them picture you in the role.   (I'm autistic and worked in HR. Most interviewers are zoned out at best, say something interesting or weirdly specific to make you stand out. I bring up projects that weren't company focused, but internally focused, making me seem more stable and long term. üëçüèΩ but also it is a tough job market even for the most qualified people... I know people with phds working part time right now)

Companies see their payroll decrease and stonks go up, but the costs are much higher than they think, it just hasn't materialized yet.

commentText: The other problem is that I guarantee that we'll see an epidemic of garbage code and security problems from software engineers who were overworked, underpaid, and told to just rely on AI. Same deal with a lot of other white collar work. We had years of education and processes for a reason. Cutting corners _does_ affect the final product. Not to mention the social ramifications of teams being ripped apart.  But I guess craftsmen would say similar of the quality of goods produced by shoddy automation. :/  Automation and AI don't have to be a bad thing. But imo it should be used to improve quality, try new things, and give workers more time and less stress, not squeeze more out of fewer people. And with more unemployed people, fewer people can afford goods and services. Unfortunately, my opinion carries no weight.

videoDescription: It's obvious that something strange is happening with the job market right now. Companies learned they no longer need local ...
commentText: I think a big part of why it‚Äôs not being talked about, is because a lot of people don‚Äôt see it as any different than the longstanding [it was already being parodied in _Office Space_ (1999) ] corporate trend of dumping employees in favor of contractors with no benefits. So this was already a huge problem, and the inclusion of foreign contractors in countries with significantly lower costs of living changes it, but doesn‚Äôt _dramatically_ change it. It‚Äôs an acceleration, not an inflection point.   Which doesn‚Äôt mean that it‚Äôs not bad or not worth talking about. And the acceleration can make a thing that was a minor problem around the edges into a society-undermining problem. But most humans are very bad at recognizing creeping threats, very bad at planning for nebulous threats, and bad-to-very-bad at cognitive empathy. So I think the lack of conversation reflects lack of recognizing that this is a systemic problem. Thanks for bringing it up!  But I also think this reflects factionalism and lack of much trans-national worker solidarity to counterbalance the power of transnational corporations. In the US, big transnational corporations and some politicians have for 50+ years mostly succeeded in scapegoating workers in lower-COL countries and pitting US workers against them. Most of the US unions completely fell for this in the 1970s-1990s, pushing to prevent offshoring of manufacturing jobs through contracts and legislation, instead of pushing to unionize the foreign workers. They saw foreign workers as unfair  competition instead of recognizing the corporations and shareholders as the source of the problem.
